page.title: 18Agriculture Around Cornard
page.content: Most of the farms in the area grow arable crops in large fields to allow machinery to work economically. Winter wheat, barley and oil-seed rape are sown in the autumn soon after the previous crop has been harvested - the land is not allowed to rest for long! A little barley is sown in the spring along with a quantity of sugar beet. Harvest time for the grain crops and rape is late summer through to autumn, and on through winter for the sugar beet. Some grain is exported, some goes for brewing, baking or animal feed. The sugar beet goes to Bury St Edmunds for processing. At Little Cornard is a herd of Jersey cows which produce milk, and at Cornard Tye is Wheldons. Few people work on the land now, perhaps only a handful full-time, and a few mums at fruit-picking time.
